items.synopsis: People in the remote community of Ltyentye Apurte are pleading with governments to not forget their struggles, following the result of the Voice referendum.

title.children: In Camilla and Leonie's community, 20 people can sleep in one house. They don't want to be forgotten

image.altText: Mother holds child in front of hospital equipment as child cries

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people are believed to be dead after a blast at a crammed Gaza hospital that Israel and Palestinian militants are blaming on each other, while regional leaders postpone meetings with Joe Biden ahead of his visit to Israel.

title.children: Israel and Palestinian militants blame each other after hospital blast kills hundreds in Gaza

image.altText: Three people move a stretcher with a man on it who is bandaged up.

items.synopsis: The meeting has been cancelled as the US president travels to Israel. Follow live for the latest updates.

title.children: Jordan cancels summit with Biden and Egyptian and Palestinian leaders amid claims of strike on Gaza hospital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai. A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians. Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed. Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan. She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government planning another repatriation flight today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai.
A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians.
Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed.
Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan.
She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reuters news agency says protests have been staged at Israel's embassies in Turkey and Jordan and near the US embassy in Lebanon, where security forces fired tear gas toward demonstrators. There have also been protests in Yemen's southwestern city of Taz, as well as in the Moroccan capital Rabat and Iraq's capital, Baghdad. Protests also took place in front of the French embassy in Tunis, Tunisia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hospital blast ignites protests in West Bank and around Middle East

children.content: The Reuters news agency says protests have been staged at Israel's embassies in Turkey and Jordan and near the US embassy in Lebanon, where security forces fired tear gas toward demonstrators.

props.alt: People protesting in the rain and a man holding a Palestinian flag

children.content: Pro-Palestinian protest near the Israeli Consulate in Istanbul, Turkey.
(Reuters: Dilara Senkaya)
There have also been protests in Yemen's southwestern city of Taz, as well as in the Moroccan capital Rabat and Iraq's capital, Baghdad.
Iraqis take part in a protest in Baghdad.
(Reuters: Ahmed Saad)
Protests also took place in front of the French embassy in Tunis, Tunisia.
People protest in front of the French embassy in Tunis.
(Reuters: Zoubeir Souissi)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jordan has cancelled a summit it was to host in Amman on Wednesday with US President Joe Biden and the Egyptian and Palestinian leaders to discuss the situation in Gaza, the country's foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, said. Biden was expected to meet the Arab leaders following a solidarity visit to Israel. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan cancels summit with Biden and Egyptian and Palestinian leaders

children.content: Jordan has cancelled a summit it was to host in Amman on Wednesday with US President Joe Biden and the Egyptian and Palestinian leaders to discuss the situation in Gaza, the country's foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, said.
Biden was expected to meet the Arab leaders following a solidarity visit to Israel.
Reporting by Reuters

image.altText: Condoleezza Rice and the five spy agency chiefs are seated onstage, with national flags behind them. Mike Burgess is speaking

items.synopsis: The domestic intelligence chiefs of Australia and the United States issue a scathing criticism of China, accusing it of intellectual property theft on an unprecedented scale.

image.altText: A composite image of raging bushfire, and a smiling man in high vis.

title.children: Coastal community cut off, schools closed as family grieves death of man killed by blaze in northern NSW

image.altText: Older man with grey hair and glasses sits on his porch with a cup of tea in hand

items.synopsis: Indigenous elders and community leaders are reacting to the weekend's No vote with shock, anger and sadness. Some say it'll be too late for them to see change in their lifetime, but are calling on Australia to do better by the next generation of First Nations people.

title.children: 'We thought Australia can't be this bad': Elders grieve Voice referendum result

image.altText: A close up photo of a man wearing a suit and blue tie.

items.synopsis: Usually in times of war Israelis put aside political differences. This time it's different — support for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has crashed, writes John Lyons.

title.children: While all eyes are on the bigger war with Gaza, small confrontations are erupting all over Israel

image.altText: A man wearing jeans and a black T-shirt sits cross-legged on the floor of a mosque

items.synopsis: When Hamas launched its attack, thousands of Gazans who were working in Israel had their permits cancelled. Away from their families, these Palestinians found themselves suddenly trapped in a country that saw them as a threat, with no way to return home.

title.children: These Palestinians were working in Israel when Hamas launched its attack. Suddenly they had no way to return home

items.synopsis: Details of a near miss emerge as Australia’s Defence Space Commander warns the skies above Earth are becoming ever "riskier".

title.children: Bullies, manipulators and narcissists: Navigating psychopathic behaviours at work

image.altText: a bushfire at night, with the whole scene lit up red, sparks flying.

items.synopsis: Backburns have been put in place with the aim of stopping the fire before it moves from scrubland into the Barkly's open plains, which are some of the NT's most productive cattle country.

title.children: Hopes backburning will slow NT fire that has burnt more than 2.8 million hectares

image.altText: Large square of green grass with no trees, in between warehouses

items.synopsis: A developer convicted and fined for illegally clearing endangered native vegetation from a Melbourne site has since been granted permission to build a multi-million-dollar development on the property.

title.children: A company illegally cleared this land. Now it's allowed to build a multi-million dollar development on it

image.altText: A man holding a rifle

items.synopsis: Guns are not a common sight in Tonga — but that is changing. An increase in crime and drug use in the small island nation is causing many to arm themselves, both legally and illegally.

title.children: 'I take my guns to church': The Tongans taking the US approach to self-defence

image.altText: A man standing outside NT Parliament House and looking serious.

items.synopsis: The Local Government Minister says he made the decision because he was satisfied "there are, or may be, serious deficiencies in the conduct of the Council's affairs".

title.children: NT government suspends Barkly Regional Council, places it under 'official management'

image.altText: An elderly Filipina woman and a younger Filipino man in formal attire, both smiling

items.synopsis: Thirty-seven years after his family fled Manilla in disgrace, Ferdinand Marcos Jr is running the country that his family had "plundered".

title.children: How this son of a dictator pulled off one of the biggest political makeovers in recent history

image.altText: Two parents hold up a child by each hand as they walk through the woods.

items.synopsis: You do not have to be perfect in order to do a good job of raising a child. In fact, it may be better if you are not, writes Cher McGillivray.

title.children: What is 'good enough parenting'? And could some 'mistakes' actually help children become resilient?

image.altText: A woman sitting on a boat holds up a small fish.

items.synopsis: Regional Victorian businesses trial a four-day work week in a bid to recruit and retain quality staff.

title.children: Grateful office manager doing 'whatever I can' to make four-day work week stick

image.altText: A green wasp standing on a purple flower

items.synopsis: An image of a rodent optic nerve head, one of almost 1,900 entries from 72 countries, takes first place in the Small World competition.

title.children: Photomicrography competition dishes up spectacular images of the teeny-tiny

image.altText: A Caucasian woman with brown hair, wearing glasses and a blazer.

items.synopsis: Local shares are set to open slightly higher, after a mixed session on Wall Street. Follow the day's financial news and insights in our live blog.

title.children: RBA governor Michele Bullock discusses inflation ahead of November rates meeting, ASX to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock has also discussed the housing market, and said she's been surprised by how it has bounced back from its initial declines. "The housing market has surprised me a bit … when COVID first hit housing prices actually declined, and then after a few months they shot up, and they shot up about 20, 25%," she said. "They really rose very, very sharply, and I should add this happened all around the world. "Now they're [house prices] back to where they were. "There's a few things going on here … one is that there's difficulties in construction of new housing … the cost of new housing has risen quite sharply, and that I think has made the equation between building a new house and buying an existing house has changed somewhat. "The equation between 'do I buy my own home or do I rent?' also shifts somewhat." She also mentioned that household size during the pandemic had declined significantly as people decided they wanted an office to work from home, no longer share with flatmates, or move further out. "A whole lot of decisions went into people having more housing stock per person," she said. "I might get the number wrong, but I saw something to the effect that that the decline was in effect the same as an additional 140,000 homes, just by that decline in household side. "Now household side has turned around a bit, and you would expect it to because rents are rising ... but nevertheless I think average household size has been another factor here that's impacted the supply and demand imbalance in the housing market."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bullock 'surprised' by resilient housing market and rising house prices

children.content: Michele Bullock has also discussed the housing market, and said she's been surprised by how it has bounced back from its initial declines.
"The housing market has surprised me a bit … when COVID first hit housing prices actually declined, and then after a few months they shot up, and they shot up about 20, 25%," she said.
"They really rose very, very sharply, and I should add this happened all around the world.
"Now they're [house prices] back to where they were.

"There's a few things going on here … one is that there's difficulties in construction of new housing … the cost of new housing has risen quite sharply, and that I think has made the equation between building a new house and buying an existing house has changed somewhat.
"The equation between 'do I buy my own home or do I rent?' also shifts somewhat."
She also mentioned that household size during the pandemic had declined significantly as people decided they wanted an office to work from home, no longer share with flatmates, or move further out.
"A whole lot of decisions went into people having more housing stock per person," she said.
"I might get the number wrong, but I saw something to the effect that that the decline was in effect the same as an additional 140,000 homes, just by that decline in household side.

"Now household side has turned around a bit, and you would expect it to because rents are rising ... but nevertheless I think average household size has been another factor here that's impacted the supply and demand imbalance in the housing market."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock was also asked about how she will approach the media in her role as RBA governor, in response to how her predecessor, Philip Lowe, was treated. She replied that dealing with the media isn't her prime focus in her job, but noted that the media have been "very focused on interest rates are rising" by certain parts of the community "who are very hurt by that". She said the RBA's independence from the government allows for the central bank to make "difficult decisions". She also gets a laugh from the crowd when she noted that Mr Lowe "copped a lot" of heat from the media before saying she thinks he got "knocked off" by former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Media criticism of former RBA governor Philip Lowe got 'knocked off' by ex-Qantas CEO Alan Joyce

children.content: Michele Bullock was also asked about how she will approach the media in her role as RBA governor, in response to how her predecessor, Philip Lowe, was treated.

She replied that dealing with the media isn't her prime focus in her job, but noted that the media have been "very focused on interest rates are rising" by certain parts of the community "who are very hurt by that".
She said the RBA's independence from the government allows for the central bank to make "difficult decisions".
She also gets a laugh from the crowd when she noted that Mr Lowe "copped a lot" of heat from the media before saying she thinks he got "knocked off" by former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bullock was asked about Australians saving more and the line from the RBA that households have more savings built up to manage higher interest rates. She said Australians "are still saving" but not as much as they normally would right now, and over the pandemic, the RBA calculated around $300 billion in excess savings were accumulated. "That hasn't really been run down yet, and it's actually the million dollar question, whether they will run it down?" she said. "There are some signs that people are starting to run it down a little bit, but there doesn't seem to be this wholesale, at the moment spending of all this money that I've suddenly got in my account. "I think there's an important reason for that ... a lot of those savings, not all, but a lot of those savings, are in offset and redraw accounts with respect to mortgages, and people tend to want to pay off their mortgages more quickly. "If anything, with higher interest rates on their mortgages at the moment, holding those savings in those offset and redraw accounts is actually very beneficial for them." She also mentions that Australia is not in a similar situation to the US right now, where they have run down their savings buffers. "The indication so far at least is that there's not a wholesale running down of buffers again," Bullock said. "That's in aggregate, there will no doubt be households that are doing that, but at an aggregate level, there's no indications yet that that's happening."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No indication we're running down savings 'on an aggregate level' yet, Bullock says

children.content: Bullock was asked about Australians saving more and the line from the RBA that households have more savings built up to manage higher interest rates.
She said Australians "are still saving" but not as much as they normally would right now, and over the pandemic, the RBA calculated around $300 billion in excess savings were accumulated.
"That hasn't really been run down yet, and it's actually the million dollar question, whether they will run it down?" she said.
"There are some signs that people are starting to run it down a little bit, but there doesn't seem to be this wholesale, at the moment spending of all this money that I've suddenly got in my account.

"I think there's an important reason for that ... a lot of those savings, not all, but a lot of those savings, are in offset and redraw accounts with respect to mortgages, and people tend to want to pay off their mortgages more quickly.
"If anything, with higher interest rates on their mortgages at the moment, holding those savings in those offset and redraw accounts is actually very beneficial for them."
She also mentions that Australia is not in a similar situation to the US right now, where they have run down their savings buffers.
"The indication so far at least is that there's not a wholesale running down of buffers again," Bullock said.
"That's in aggregate, there will no doubt be households that are doing that, but at an aggregate level, there's no indications yet that that's happening."

title.children: Australian journalist detained for three years in China was accused of breaching media embargo

image.altText: Owen Farrell gives the thumbs up

items.synopsis: New Zealand and South Africa reached the Rugby World Cup semifinals after brutal wins against the top-two ranked teams in the world. England and Argentina have not had nearly as tough a road on paper, but that will mean nothing come this weekend.

title.children: Rugby World Cup semifinals pits two clear favourites against two teams lucky to be there

image.altText: Five people standing in a asia grocery store. Man in the middle wearing red tinged glasses.

title.children: 'You look like Nicolas Cage': Shop owner's suspicions confirmed as Hollywood actor browses Busselton

image.altText: a close-up image of a woman's hand holding a vape. smoke can be seen coming from her nose and moutn

image.altText: cars in rain

items.synopsis: SUVs now outsell passenger cars three to one, even as petrol prices have risen. What's driving our love of large vehicles, asks Peter Martin, and how can we make them cheaper and safer?

title.children: SUVs now outsell passenger cars three to one, even as petrol prices have risen. What's driving our love of large vehicles?

image.altText: A woman in a red beret and dress sits in front of a large and very well stocked bookshelf

items.synopsis: As much as we like to pretend it doesn't, the designs of book covers can tell us a lot about what we might find inside. From colourful blobs to minimalist chic, we help you decode what's on your shelf.

title.children: Why it really is OK to judge a book by its cover (and what those covers say about you)

title.children: After years of growth, farmland sales hit a turning point as owners brace for dry weather, lower commodity prices

title.children: $80,000 for damaging a tree: Canberra's tough new laws to protect urban forest

image.altText: Injuries to a police officer following an alleged assault.

title.children: Woman accused of 'pulling actual clumps of hair' out of police officer's scalp pleads not guilty
